object.property: Filesystem template that uses a plugin for VMware ESX server
A record for CPU usage by a single virtual machine.
Share of CPU allocated to vm by vmkernel.
CPU Usage table by virtual machine.
Time the virtual machine has been running on the CPU (seconds).
ID allocated to running vm by the vmkernel.
Share of disk bandwidth allocated to this vm.
A record for a single hba on the machine.
ID assigned to running vm by the vmkernel.
MAC address of vm's virtual NIC.
Kilobytes read from this disk since disk module was loaded.
Kilobytes received on this NIC since network module was loaded.
Kilobytes sent from this NIC since network module was loaded.
Kilobytes written to this disk since disk module was loaded.
Amount of physical memory used by the console OS (KB).
Amount of memory the vm was configured with. (KB)
A record for memory usage by a single virtual machine.
Shares of memory allocated to vm by vmkernel.
Amount of physical memory present on machine (KB).
Table of memory usage by virtual machine.
Amount of memory utilized by the vm. (KB; instantaneous)
ID allocated to running vm by the vmkernel.
A record for a single nic on the machine.
String describing the network adapter. Format: vmnic*
Share of net bandwidth allocated to this vm. (NOT IMPLEMENTED)
ID assigned to running vm by the vmkernel.
Number of physical CPUs on the system.
Number of reads to this disk since disk module was loaded.
Number of writes to this disk since disk module was loaded.
Number of pkts received on this NIC since network module was loaded.
Number of pkts transmitted on this NIC since network module was loaded.
Disk adapter and target information table.
Version-specific unique OID for product in the VMware MIB.
This is the config file of the affected vm generating the trap.
This is the ID of the affected vm generating the trap. If the vmID is non-existent, (such as for a power-off trap) -1 is returned.
This trap is sent when a virtual machine detects or regains the guest heartbeat.
This trap is sent when a virtual machine detects a loss in guest heartbeat.
This trap is sent when a virtual machine is powered OFF.
This trap is sent when a virtual machine is powered ON from a suspended or a powered off state.
This trap is sent when a virtual machine is suspended.
This number corresponds to the vm's index in the VM info table.
Record for a single CDROM drive.
Index into CDROM table. Order of the CDROM device on this vm.
Device number/name (/dev/CDROM, etc. NULL if not present).
Table of CDROM drives seen by this vm.
Index into floppy table. Order of the floppy device on this vm.
Device number/name (/dev/fd0, etc. NULL if not present).
This number corresponds to the vm's index in the VM info table.
Record for a single floppy drive.
Table of floppy drives seen by this vm.
Record for a single host bus adapter.
VM's virtual SCSI adapter number; second part of the table index.
Table of disk adapters seen by this vm.
Virtual SCSI target number; second part of target entry index.
Table of scsi targets seen by this vm.
This number corresponds to the vm's index in the VM info table.
Virtual device type for this adapter.
This number corresponds to the vm's index in the VM info table.
Table of network adapters seen by this vm.
This number corresponds to the vm's index in the VM info table.
Path to the configuration file for this vm.
Name by which this vm is displayed.
The record for a single virtual machine.
Operating system running on this vm.
Guest operating system ON or OFF.
This is a dummy number for an index.
A table containing information on virtual machines that have been configured on the system.

If a VM is active, an ID is assigned to it (like a pid). Some VMs may have been configured but not running. Information about these VMs without VM IDs is also displayed, so we can't use VM ID as the table's index.
